It was known to Petrarch, who in his eanzone ‘ Spirto gentil ’ addressed to the Roman Senator Bosone da Gubbio in 1336 or 1337, in which he conjures him to make an end of the factions in Rome, and to restore the city to its ancient freedom and greatness,¹ echoes Dante's phrase ‘Roma nunc Hannibali nedum alii miseranda ' (ll. 142-4) in the line ‘Ch’ Annibale, non ch' altri, farian pio' (l. 65).² The letter was also known to Rienzi, who introduced many phrases from it in his own letter (written in 1351) to the Cardinal Guy de Boulogne.³ The Dantesque
